G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters concerning legal and physical custody, parenting time, and support of the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 3, as the prior custody and parenting‑time judgment was issued by this Court on April 15, 2018.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters concerning legal and physical custody, parenting time, and support of the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 3, as the prior custody and parenting‑time judgment was issued by this Court on April 15, 2018.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters concerning legal and physical custody, parenting time, and support of the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 3, as the prior custody and parenting‑time judgment was issued by this Court on April 15, 2018.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3; G.L. c. 223A, \u0.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court because the prior judgment was entered in this Court and the child presently resides within the jurisdiction of this Court. See G.L. c. 215, § 3; G.L. c. 223A, § 3.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court because the prior judgment was entered in this Court and the child presently resides within the jurisdiction of this Court. See G.L. c. 215, § 3; G.L. c. 223A, § 3.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28 (1).proposition: This Complaint for Modification is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the Court’s inherent equity powers to revise and alter custody and parenting orders when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and modification is necessary in the best interests of the child. See, e.g., *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: This Complaint for Modification is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the Court’s inherent equity powers to revise and alter custody and parenting orders when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and modification is necessary in the best interests of the child. See, e.g., *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/relocation and initial custody case arising in the context of a divorce judgment, not a complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The opinion interprets G.L. c. 208, § 30 and articulates the ‘real advantage’ and best‑interests standards for permitting a custodial parent to remove children from the Commonwealth, but it does not discuss the material and substantial change in circumstances requirement or the court’s modification authority under § 28. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific procedural and substantive standard described in the proposition.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815) …”}

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: This Complaint for Modification is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and the Court’s inherent equity powers to revise and alter custody and parenting orders when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and modification is necessary in the best interests of the child. See, e.g., *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly interprets and applies G.L. c. 208, § 28 in the context of a complaint for modification of custody, stating that a modification judgment may be entered only upon a finding of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the modification must be necessary in the best interests of the child. The court reverses the custody modification because those statutory standards were not met, thereby affirming the principle that the court’s equity-based power to revise custody orders is conditioned on such a change and a best‑interests determination. Although it does not explicitly use the phrase “inherent equity powers,” its discussion of the court’s continuing power to modify orders under § 28 is consistent with that proposition.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

*Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 105, 112 (20.proposition: Since entry of the 2018 Judgment, there have been material and substantial changes in circumstances, as recognized by Massachusetts law, such that the existing parenting‑time schedule is no longer in the minor child’s best interests. See *Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 105, 112 (2009) (modification requires showing of “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” and that modification is in the child’s best interests); *Cooper v. Keto*, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798, 802–03 (2013) (same).
*Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 105, 112 (20.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about suppression of evidence in a child pornography prosecution and addresses probable cause, seizure of a computer, and execution of a search warrant. It does not concern domestic relations, custody, parenting time, or modification standards, and nowhere discusses a requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances or best interests of a child. The citation to Schuh v. Schuh, 453 Mass. 105 (2009), for a family‑law modification standard is therefore incorrect and unsupported by this text, which appears to be a different case despite the same caption and volume/page citation.
*Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 105, 112 (20.relevant_excerpt: A search warrant may issue only on a showing of probable cause. Commonwealth v. Byfield, 413 Mass. 426, 428 (1992). Under the Fourth Amendment and art. 14, probable cause requires a “substantial basis,” Commonwealth v. Stewart, 358 Mass. 747, 749 (1971), for concluding that “the items sought are related to the criminal activity under investigation, and that they reasonably may be expected to be located in the place to be searched at the time the search warrant issues.” Commonwealth v. Cinelli, 389 Mass. 197, 213, cert. denied, 464 U.S. 860 (1983).

*Cooper v. Keto*, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798,.proposition: Since entry of the 2018 Judgment, there have been material and substantial changes in circumstances, as recognized by Massachusetts law, such that the existing parenting‑time schedule is no longer in the minor child’s best interests. See *Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. 105, 112 (2009) (modification requires showing of “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” and that modification is in the child’s best interests); *Cooper v. Keto*, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798, 802–03 (2013) (same).
*Cooper v. Keto*, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798,.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Cooper v. Keto is a concurring opinion focused on the disproportionate cost of litigation and advising restraint in bringing actions; it does not discuss standards for modification of parenting time, material and substantial change in circumstances, or best interests of the child. While the main Cooper opinion (outside this excerpt) may address those issues, the text supplied here does not support the cited legal proposition. Thus, based solely on this text, the citation is not supported.
*Cooper v. Keto*, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798,.relevant_excerpt: "Here, we again witness another puzzling situation in which the legal fees paid and awarded far exceed any amount that would be gained. Indeed, the father has acknowledged that the costs associated with defending the action might better have been spent on the child’s college education. Litigation should be the last option, not the first."

*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619, 625\.proposition: The current schedule was appropriate when Ethan was very young and not in full‑day school, but it has become impractical and unnecessarily disruptive as Ethan has entered school age and has increased academic, social, and rest needs. See *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619, 625–26 (2000) (best‑interests determination must consider child’s age and developmental needs).
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619, 625\.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that Williams v. Massa holds that a best‑interests determination must consider the child’s age and developmental needs, in support of modifying a visitation schedule for a school‑age child. While the opinion discusses the children’s special needs and critiques the custody mechanism used (requiring a modification complaint instead of a motion), it does not articulate a general rule that the best‑interests analysis must account for a child’s age, developmental stage, or changing school‑related needs. The cited pages focus on property division and the procedural vehicle for custody changes, not on evolving schedules as children grow older, so the case does not directly support the specific proposition stated.
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619, 625\.relevant_excerpt: “A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan.”

*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616.proposition: Ethan has repeatedly expressed a desire to have actual sleepovers and overnight parenting time at Father’s home, where he now has his own bedroom and personal space. While a child’s wishes are not controlling, they are a relevant factor when considering the child’s best interests, particularly as the child grows older. See *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616–17 (1987) (child’s preferences may be considered among many factors).
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses the weight to be given a child’s custodial preference. It states that the preference of a ten-year-old is not decisive but is a factor to be considered, and then cites several Massachusetts cases. This aligns with the proposition that a child’s wishes, while not controlling, are a relevant factor in best-interests determinations, particularly as the child grows older.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616.relevant_excerpt:
“Tony’s custody presents a closer question… On balance, however, the judge’s decision… is not plainly wrong. 

The preference of someone Tony’s age (ten at the time of the proceedings) is not given decisive weight, although it is a factor to be considered. See Dumain v. Gwynne… Stone v. Duffy… Custody of a Minor… Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… Hale v. Hale…. The judge could give consideration to the report of one of the court’s family service officers…”

*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.proposition: An agreed‑upon change in parenting time, when consistent with the child’s best interests, is an appropriate basis for modification. See *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 815–16 (1981).
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses removal of children from the Commonwealth and the factors relevant to a relocation decision, not modification of a parenting-time order based on an agreed-upon change in parenting time. The court discusses best interests in terms of relocation and alternative visitation schedules, but does not involve a modification proceeding grounded in the parties’ agreement about parenting time. Thus, it does not establish or affirm the specific proposition that an agreed-upon change in parenting time, when consistent with the child’s best interests, is an appropriate basis for modification.
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.relevant_excerpt: “He did not discuss the possibility of alternate visiting schedules which would preserve and foster the important relationship of the children with their father. He also did not consider whether support payments could be reduced (as offered by the wife) to cover visitation expenses, nor did he inquire if the husband, who had a former career in the Air Force, had access to free or reduced air fares.”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 547\.proposition: The conditions and assumptions that formed the basis of the 2018 Judgment—primarily, Father’s limited and unsuitable housing and Ethan’s very young age and lack of school obligations—have materially changed, and the present circumstances warrant revision of the parenting‑time arrangement. See *Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 547–48 (2010) (material change may be shown where assumptions underlying earlier order have significantly changed).
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 547\.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald is a concurring opinion focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the limits of a judge’s authority to order a relocating, sole-legal parent to return to Massachusetts. It does not address modification of existing custody or parenting-time orders based on a material change in circumstances or changed underlying assumptions. The proposition about material change in circumstances and revision of parenting time is therefore not supported by this case or the cited pages.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540, 547\.relevant_excerpt: "After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate."

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494\u20.proposition: Continuing to enforce the 2018 Judgment without modification subjects Ethan to an unnecessarily fragmented, exhausting schedule that is no longer aligned with his best interests, his schooling, or his expressed wish for extended and overnight time with Father. See *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494–95 (2012) (paramount consideration is best interests of the child).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494\u20.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modifying an existing custody/parenting-time judgment because the current schedule is fragmented, exhausting, and no longer in the child’s best interests, including his schooling and expressed wishes. Hunter v. Rose does state that the paramount consideration in custody matters is the child’s best interests, and discusses factors like stability and parental conduct, but it does so in the context of an initial custody determination, not modification of an already-entered judgment or schedule. Thus, while the case supports the general best-interests principle, it does not specifically support the asserted proposition about continuing to enforce a 2018 Judgment without modification for this child and these circumstances.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494\u20.relevant_excerpt: “‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] . . . what is ‘best for the child’. . . .’ Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003). ‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge . . . [whose] findings . . . ‘must stand unless they are plainly wrong.’’ Id. at 845, quoting Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191 (1998). However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’”}

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.proposition: By contrast, establishing a more age‑appropriate schedule that includes regular overnight parenting time with Father and reduces the number of short mid‑week transitions will promote Ethan’s stability, rest, academic success, emotional well‑being, and his relationship with each parent, and will better serve his overall best interests. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003) (courts seek arrangements that provide stability and continuity while fostering child’s relationship with both parents); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 900 (1981) (modification appropriate where change promotes child’s welfare).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Custody of Kali for the general principle that courts seek custody/parenting arrangements that promote stability and continuity while fostering the child’s relationship with both parents. The opinion does clearly articulate that stability, continuity with the existing caregiving arrangement, and preservation of bonds with both parents are central to the best‑interests analysis. However, it does not speak specifically about “age‑appropriate schedules,” “reducing mid‑week transitions,” or overnight parenting time; those specifics are the user’s application of the general stability/relationship principles, not something expressly discussed in Kali.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.… The judgment was structured to ensure that both parents…would be able to preserve, foster, and strengthen those relationships.”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: By contrast, establishing a more age‑appropriate schedule that includes regular overnight parenting time with Father and reduces the number of short mid‑week transitions will promote Ethan’s stability, rest, academic success, emotional well‑being, and his relationship with each parent, and will better serve his overall best interests. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003) (courts seek arrangements that provide stability and continuity while fostering child’s relationship with both parents); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 900 (1981) (modification appropriate where change promotes child’s welfare).
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The proposition cites Bouchard for the idea that a modification is appropriate where a change promotes the child’s welfare. Bouchard does not discuss modification standards or endorse a particular change in schedule; instead, it vacates a custody award because the judge failed to apply the correct best‑interests criteria and remands for further findings. The case supports only the general principle that custody decisions must be grounded in the child’s welfare, not specifically that a modification is appropriate when a change promotes that welfare.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 181\u.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, this Court has broad equitable authority to revise and alter custody and parenting‑time provisions when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred and modification is required to serve the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 181–82 (2006); *Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. at 112.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 181\u.support_reasoning: The cited portion of Mason v. Coleman deals with the standard for removal of children from the Commonwealth under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in the context of joint physical custody, focusing on a best‑interests analysis and abuse‑of‑discretion review. It does not discuss the court’s broad equitable authority to revise or alter custody and parenting‑time provisions upon a material and substantial change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28, nor does it frame relocation as a § 28 modification issue. Thus it does not provide direct authority for the specific modification proposition claimed.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 181\u.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ … Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595.proposition: The proposed modification is sought solely to promote the best interests and welfare of Ethan, consistent with Massachusetts law, which holds that the “overriding and paramount concern” in any custody or parenting‑time determination is the best interests of the child. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. at 494–95 (2012).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595.support_reasoning: The opinion is clearly a custody case framed around assessing the impact of domestic violence on the child and repeatedly references the statutory and doctrinal requirement to consider the best interests of the child in custody determinations. While the quoted pages emphasize the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects, they do so explicitly in the context of determining what custody arrangement is in the child’s best interests, consistent with Massachusetts law. The case therefore supports the general proposition that the paramount concern in custody/parenting‑time determinations is the child’s best interests, even though it focuses specifically on domestic violence rather than restating the general formula in those exact words.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595.relevant_excerpt: “The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. … The Appeals Court’s remand order is designed to do just that. We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm.”

G.L. c. 71, \u00a7 34H.proposition:
Establish any additional provisions the Court deems appropriate to ensure consistent homework, bedtime, transportation, and communication arrangements between the parents, including but not limited to:

     i. Clear exchange times and locations;  
     ii. Provisions for school‑related communication and access to school records, in accordance with G.L. c. 71, § 34H; and  
     iii. Any other terms that promote Ethan’s stability, continuity, and well‑being.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Mother further requests that this Court enter any additional orders that it deems just and proper to effectuate the modified custody and parenting‑time arrangement in Ethan’s best interests, consistent with the Court’s authority under G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 215, § 6; and applicable case law (*Mason v. Coleman*; *Custody of Kali*; *Custody of Vaughn*).
